nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Sitting Down at the Table
nodes.text: You and your co-parent sit across from each other. The air is stiff but both of you agreed: tonight is about making some basic agreements for the child.

choices.label: Start with something positive about the co-parent.
choices.text: You begin: “Thanks for meeting. I know this isn’t easy, but I appreciate that you’re here.”

choices.label: Dive straight into problems about the schedule.
choices.text: You skip the warm-up: “This schedule is not working. We need to fix it.”

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: What Matters Most?
nodes.text: Your co-parent shifts in their chair. “I just want things to be fair. I feel like I’m carrying more than you.”

choices.label: Bring the focus back to the child.
choices.text: “I get that. Can we talk about what our child needs first, and then look at what’s fair for us?”

choices.label: Defend yourself point by point.
choices.text: “That’s not true. I’m doing a lot too, you just don’t see it.”

choices.label: Acknowledge feelings but park the debate.
choices.text: “I hear that you feel that way. Can we write down what each of us does later and first agree on a basic weekly plan?”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Drafting the First Agreement
nodes.text: You pull out a piece of paper or open a shared note. The question is simple but loaded: where does the child sleep on school nights?

choices.label: Propose a clear, realistic plan with built-in review.
choices.text: You suggest: “Let’s try this schedule for four weeks and then review. If it’s not working, we adjust together.”

choices.label: Push for a plan that mostly suits you.
choices.text: You push for a schedule that gives you the days you prefer, brushing off the co-parent’s concerns.

choices.label: Keep everything vague to avoid conflict for now.
choices.text: You say, “Let’s just keep it flexible and see how it goes,” and avoid writing anything down.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Closing the Conversation
nodes.text: The conversation winds down. The plan may not be perfect, but it’s a starting point. The way you both showed up tonight will echo in how safe the child feels.

choices.label: End scene and return to menu.
choices.text: You take a breath, thank each other, and close the notebook.

choices.label: Take a moment to reflect on what you learned.
choices.text: You pause for a moment before leaving the table and ask yourself what actually went well tonight.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Quick Reflection
nodes.text: If you replay this conversation in your mind, what stands out more: the conflict, or the fact that you both stayed at the table long enough to reach a starting point?

choices.label: Notice the progress — even if small.
choices.text: You focus on the fact that you created at least one concrete agreement together.

choices.label: Notice how drained you feel.
choices.text: You register how exhausting these talks are and make a note to plan recovery time next time as well.
